rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you. See [[WP:FIXNF]] and [[WP:10CR]]
rev.diff:
Line 631: Line 631:
== Coach of the Year ==
== Coach of the Year ==
â
[[File:Bo Schembechler promo.jpg|thumb|upright|Bo Schembechler won the first MAC Coach of the Year award at Miami University.]]
 
[[File:Urban Meyer spring2008practice1.jpg|thumb|upright|Urban Meyer won the award in 2001 with Bowling Green, before coaching at Utah and Florida.]]
[[File:Urban Meyer spring2008practice1.jpg|thumb|upright|Urban Meyer won the award in 2001 with Bowling Green, before coaching at Utah and Florida.]]
The MAC has awarded a Coach of the Year award every year since 1965. The first award went to [[Bo Schembechler]] of [[Miami RedHawks football|Miami University]]. Only one coach has won the award more than twice, with [[Frank Lauterbur]] winning the award in 1967, 1969, and 1970.<ref name="coach of the year" group="ref"/> Only two coaches has won the award beyond their tenth year of coaching. [[Bill Hess]] won the award in 1968 in his 11th year of coaching the [[Ohio Bobcats football|Ohio Bobcats]] and [[Herb Deromedi]] won the award in 1990, his 13th year of coaching [[Central Michigan Chippewas football|Central Michigan]].<ref name="coaching records" group="ref"/> Also, only one coach, [[Bill Mallory]], has won the award coaching two separate teams. He first earned the award in 1973 while coaching Miami University, and then won ten years later giving [[Northern Illinois Huskies football|Northern Illinois]] their first Coach of the Year award. [[Toledo Rockets football|Toledo]] leads all schools with nine awards. [[Temple Owls football|Temple]] won their first award in [[2009 NCAA Division I FBS football season|2009]] when head coach [[Al Golden (American football)|Al Golden]] won his first MAC Coach of the Year award.<ref name="2009 awards" group="ref"/>

He first earned the award in 1973 while coaching Miami University, and then won ten years later giving [[Northern Illinois Huskies football|Northern Illinois]] their first Coach of the Year award. [[Toledo Rockets football|Toledo]] leads all schools with nine awards.
